msgSnippet: Of course, in some situations like protocol testing you still need order dependency. But I would put all the methods in a sequence where order matters in a

Of course, in some situations like protocol testing you still need order
dependency.

But I would put all the methods in a sequence where order matters in a
single test case.
That also makes logging and other tracking easier on the eyes...

Jim JM

-----Original Message-----
From: Johannes Link [mailto:john.link@...]
Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2001 5:36 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Order of Tests


You should forgo the dependance on the order of the tests. This is what
setUp() and tearDown() usually take care of.
When you rely on a certain order what do your follow-up tests do when
one of their precessors has failed? Removing test order dependeny often
requires some refactoring of the tests and of the classes under tests.
Every time that I had to do this refactoring I ended up with an improved
design, i.e. one with less overall dependencies and better overall
testability.

Johannes

Heinz van Pee wrote:
>
> Hello,
> i have a question about JUnit:
> Is it possible to influence the order of the Tests?
> I have some test methods in a Testcase and would like to
> have them executed in a specific order, for some tests
> reley on the success of others.
> Is there any way to do this?
>
> Kind Regards,
>     Heinz van Pee
